author: Geoffrey Chaucer
text: Whan that Aprille with his shour
The droghte of March hath perc
d every veyne in swich licóur
Whan Zephirus eek with his swet
d hath in every holt and heeth
Hath in the Ram his half
That slepen al the nyght with open y
So priketh hem Natúre in hir corag
Thanne longen folk to goon on pilgrimag
And palmeres for to seken straung
The hooly blisful martir for to sek
That hem hath holpen whan that they were seek
Bifil that in that seson on a day,
In Southwerk at the Tabard as I lay,
Redy to wenden on my pilgrymag
To Caunterbury with ful devout corag
At nyght were come into that hostelry
Wel nyne and twenty in a compaigny
Of sondry folk, by áventure y-fall
In felaweshipe, and pilgrimes were they all
So hadde I spoken with hem everychon,
That I was of hir felaweshipe anon,
To take oure wey, ther as I yow devys
lees, whil I have tyme and spac
Er that I ferther in this tal
Me thynketh it acordaunt to resoun
Of ech of hem, so as it sem
And whiche they weren and of what degree,
And eek in what array that they were inn
And at a Knyght than wol I first bigynn
A Knyght ther was, and that a worthy man,
Trouthe and honóur, fredom and curteisi
Ful worthy was he in his lord
And thereto hadde he riden, no man ferr
As wel in cristendom as in heth
At Alisaundre he was whan it was wonn
tyme he hadde the bord bigonn
No cristen man so ofte of his degree.
In Gernade at the seege eek hadde he be
Of Algezir, and riden in Belmary
At Lyeys was he, and at Sataly
Whan they were wonne; and in the Gret
At many a noble armee hadde he be.
At mortal batailles hadde he been fiften
And foughten for oure feith at Tramyssen
s, and ay slayn his foo.
And evermoore he hadde a sovereyn prys.
And though that he were worthy, he was wys,
And of his port as meeke as is a mayd
He nevere yet no vileynye ne sayd
In al his lyf, unto no maner wight.
He was a verray, parfit, gentil knyght.
But for to tellen yow of his array,
For he was late y-come from his viag
With hym ther was his sone, a yong Squiér,
A lovyere and a lusty bacheler,
s crulle as they were leyd in press
Of twenty yeer of age he was, I gess
Of his statúre he was of evene length
And wonderly delyvere and of greet strength
And he hadde been somtyme in chyvachi
And born hym weel, as of so litel spac
In hope to stonden in his lady grac
Embrouded was he, as it were a meed
Syngynge he was, or floytynge, al the day;
He was as fressh as is the month of May.
Short was his gowne, with slev
Wel koude he sitte on hors and fair
Juste and eek daunce, and weel purtreye and writ
He sleep namoore than dooth a nyghtyngal
Curteis he was, lowely and servysábl
And carf biforn his fader at the tabl
A Yeman hadde he and servántz namo
At that tyme, for hym list
And he was clad in cote and hood of gren
Under his belt he bar ful thriftily—
Wel koude he dresse his takel yemanly;
And in his hand he baar a myghty bow
A not-heed hadde he, with a broun viság
craft wel koude he al the uság
Upon his arm he baar a gay bracér,
And by his syde a swerd and a bokeler,
And on that oother syde a gay dagger
d wel and sharp as point of sper
A Cristophere on his brest of silver sheen
An horn he bar, the bawdryk was of gren
A forster was he, soothly as I gess
Ther was also a Nonne, a Prioress
That of hir smylyng was ful symple and coy;
Hire gretteste ooth was but by seint
Ful weel she soong the servic
d in hir nose ful sem
And Frenssh she spak ful faire and fetisly,
After the scole of Stratford att
For Frenssh of Parys was to hire unknow
She leet no morsel from hir lipp
Wel koude she carie a morsel and wel kep
Thát no drope ne fille upon hire brist;
In curteisie was set ful muchel hir list.
That in hir coppe ther was no ferthyng sen
, whan she dronken hadde hir draught
ly after hir mete she raught
And sikerly she was of greet desport,
And ful plesáunt and amyable of port,
Of court, and been estatlich of maner
And to ben holden digne of reverenc
But for to speken of hire consc
She was so charitable and so pitous
wepe if that she saugh a mous
Kaught in a trappe, if it were deed or bledd
s hadde she, that she fedd
With rosted flessh, or milk and wastel breed;
wepte she if oon of hem were deed,
Or if men smoot it with a yerd
Hire nose tretys, her eyen greye as glas,
Hir mouth ful smal and ther-to softe and reed;
But sikerly she hadde a fair forheed;
For, hardily, she was nat undergrow
Ful fetys was hir cloke, as I was war;
Of smal coral aboute hire arm she bar
And ther-on heng a brooch of gold ful sheen
On which ther was first write a crown
A Monk ther was, a fair for the maistri
A manly man, to been an abbot abl
Ful many a deyntee hors hadde he in stabl
And whan he rood, men myghte his brydel heer
Gýnglen in a whistlynge wynd als cleer
And eek as loude, as dooth the chapel bell
Ther as this lord was kepere of the cell
The reule of seint Maure or of seint Beneit,
By-cause that it was old and som-del streit,—
He yaf nat of that text a pull
That seith that hunters ben nat hooly men,
Ne that a monk, whan he is recch
d til a fissh that is waterlees,—
This is to seyn, a monk out of his cloystr
text heeld he nat worth an oystr
And I seyde his opinioun was good.
What sholde he studie and make hymselven wood,
Upon a book in cloystre alwey to pour
As Austyn bit? How shal the world be serv
Lat Austyn have his swynk to him reserv
Therfore he was a prikasour aright:
Grehoundes he hadde, as swift as fowel in flight;
Of prikyng and of huntyng for the har
Was al his lust, for no cost wolde he spar
I seigh his sleves y-púrfiled at the hond
With grys, and that the fyneste of a lond;
And for to festne his hood under his chyn
He hadde of gold y-wroght a curious pyn;
A love-knotte in the gretter ende ther was.
His heed was balled, that shoon as any glas,
And eek his face, as he hadde been enoynt.
He was a lord ful fat and in good poynt;
His eyen stepe, and rollynge in his heed,
d as a forneys of a leed;
s souple, his hors in greet estaat.
Now certeinly he was a fair prelaat.
He was nat pale, as a forpyn
A fat swan loved he best of any roost.
His palfrey was as broun as is a bery
A Frere ther was, a wantowne and a mery
s foure is noon that kan
So muchel of daliaunce and fair langag
Unto his ordre he was a nobl
Ful wel biloved and famulier was he
With frankeleyns over al in his contree,
And eek with worthy wommen of the toun;
For he hadde power of confess
For of his ordre he was licenciat.
He was an esy man to yeve penaunc
There as he wiste to have a good pitaunc
that a man is wel y-shryv
For, if he yaf, he dorst
He wiste that a man was répentaunt;
For many a man so hard is of his hert
He may nat wepe al-thogh hym soor
Therfore in stede of wepynge and preyér
Men moote yeve silver to the povr
And certeinly he hadde a murye not
Wel koude he synge and pleyen on a rot
Ther-to he strong was as a champioun.
He knew the tavernes wel in every toun,
Bet than a lazar or a beggester
For unto swich a worthy man as he
Acorded nat, as by his facultee,
It is nat honest, it may nat avaunc
Fór to deelen with no swich poraill
But al with riche and selleres of vitaill
And over-al, ther as profit sholde aris
Curteis he was and lowely of servys
Ther nas no man nowher so vertuous.
Noon of his brethren cam ther in his haunt;]
Yet wolde he have a ferthyng er he went
And rage he koude, as it were right a whelp
For there he was nat lyk a cloysterer
With a thredbare cope, as is a povre scolér,
But he was lyk a maister, or a pop
That rounded as a belle, out of the press
To make his Englissh sweete upon his tong
And in his harpyng, whan that he hadde songe,
This worthy lymytour was cleped Hubérd.
A Marchant was ther with a fork
leye, and hye on horse he sat;
Upon his heed a Flaundryssh bevere hat;
His resons he spak ful solémpn
Sownynge alway thencrees of his wynnyng.
He wolde the see were kept for any thing
This worthy man ful wel his wit bisett
no wight that he was in dett
So estatly was he of his gouvernaunc
With his bargaynes and with his chevyssaunc
For sothe he was a worthy man with-all
But, sooth to seyn, I noot how men hym call
A Clerk ther was of Oxenford also,
was his hors as is a rak
And he nas nat right fat, I undertak
Ful thredbare was his overeste court
For he hadde geten hym yet no benefic
Ne was so worldly for to have offic
For hym was lévere háve at his bedd
s, clad in blak or reed,
s riche, or fíthele, or gay sautri
But al be that he was a philosophr
he but litel gold in cofr
But al that he myghte of his freend
s and on lernynge he it spent
And bisily gan for the soul
Of hem that yaf hym wher-with to scoley
Of studie took he moost cure and moost heed
Noght o word spak he moor
And that was seyd in forme and reverenc
And short and quyk and ful of hy senténc
Sownynge in moral vertu was his spech
And gladly wolde he lerne and gladly tech
Ther was also, ful riche of excellenc
Discreet he was, and of greet reverenc
Justice he was ful often in assis
By patente, and by pleyn commiss
For his science and for his heigh renoun,
So greet a purchasour was nowher noon:
Al was fee symple to hym in effect;
Nowher so bisy a man as he ther nas,
s hadde he caas and doom
That from the tyme of kyng William were fall
Ther-to he koude endite and make a thyng,
no wight pynche at his writyng;
And every statut koude he pleyn by rot
He rood but hoomly in a medlee cot
Girt with a ceint of silk, with barr
Of his array telle I no lenger tal
Whit was his berd as is the day
Wel loved he by the morwe a sop in wyn;
To lyven in delit was evere his won
An housholdere, and that a greet, was he;
Seint Julian he was in his contree.
His breed, his ale, was alweys after oon;
Of fissh and flessh, and that so plent
d in his hous of mete and drynk
After the sondry sesons of the yeer;
d he his mete and his soper.
Ful many a fat partrich hadde he in muw
And many a breem and many a luce in stuw
Wo was his cook but if his sauc
Poynaunt and sharp, and redy al his geer
His table dormant in his halle alway
At sessiouns ther was he lord and sir
tyme he was knyght of the shir
An anlaas, and a gipser al of silk,
Heeng at his girdel, whit as morn
A shirreve hadde he been, and a countour;
Was nowher such a worthy vavasour.
A Webbe, a Dyere, and a Tapycer,—
Of a solémpne and a greet fraternitee.
Ful fressh and newe hir geere apik
But al with silver; wroght ful clene and weel
d ech of hem a fair burgeys
To sitten in a yeldehalle, on a deys.
Éverich, for the wisdom that he kan,
Was shaply for to been an alderman;
It is ful fair to been y-cleped
And have a mantel roialliche y-bor
Wel koude he knowe a draughte of Londoun al
rooste, and sethe, and broille, and fry
Máken mortreux, and wel bake a py
But greet harm was it, as it thought
That on his shyne a mormal hadd
For blankmanger, that made he with the best
A Shipman was ther, wonynge fer by west
For aught I woot he was of Dert
He rood upon a rouncy, as he kouth
In a gowne of faldyng to the knee.
A daggere hangynge on a laas hadde he
Aboute his nekke, under his arm adoun.
somer hadde maad his hewe al broun;
And certeinly he was a good felaw
Ful many a draughte of wyn hadde he y-draw
Fro Burdeux-ward, whil that the chapman sleep.
If that he faught and hadde the hyer hond,
By water he sente hem hoom to every lond.
But of his craft to rekene wel his tyd
s, and his daungers hym bisid
His herberwe and his moone, his lode-menag
Ther nas noon swich from Hull
Hardy he was and wys to undertak
With many a tempest hadde his berd been shak
From Gootlond to the Cape of Fynyster
And every cryke in Britaigne and in Spayn
With us ther was a Doctour of Phisik;
In all this world ne was ther noon hym lik,
To speke of phisik and of surgery
For he was grounded in astronomy
Wel koude he fortunen the ascendent
Of his ymáges for his pac
He knew the cause of everich malady
Were it of hoot, or cold, or moyste, or dry
And where they engendred and of what humour.
He was a verray, parfit praktisour;
The cause y-knowe, and of his harm the root
Ful redy hadde he his apothecari
For ech of hem made oother for to wynn
For it was of no superfluitee,
But of greet norissyng and digestíbl
His studie was but litel on the Bibl
In sangwyn and in pers he clad was al,
d with taffata and with sendal.
And yet he was but esy of dispenc
For gold in phisik is a cord
A Good Wif was ther of bisid
But she was som-del deef, and that was scath
In al the parisshe wif ne was ther noon
That to the offrynge bifore hire shold
And if ther dide, certeyn so wrooth was she
That she was out of all
That on a Sonday weren upon hir heed.
Hir hosen weren of fyn scarlet reed,
Ful streite y-teyd, and shoes ful moyste and new
Boold was hir face, and fair, and reed of hew
She was a worthy womman al hir lyv
But ther-of nedeth nat to speke as nowth
s hadde she been at Jérusalem;
In Galice at Seint Jame, and at Coloign
muchel of wandrynge by the wey
d was she, soothly for to sey
Upon an amblere esily she sat,
d wel, and on hir heed an hat
As brood as is a bokeler or a targ
And on hire feet a paire of spor
In felaweshipe wel koude she laughe and carp
Of remedies of love she knew
For she koude of that art the old
A good man was ther of relig
But riche he was of hooly thoght and werk.
His parisshens devoutly wolde he tech
Benygne he was, and wonder diligent,
Ful looth were hym to cursen for his tith
But rather wolde he yeven, out of dout
Of his offrýng and eek of his substaunc
He koude in litel thyng have suffisaunc
Wyd was his parisshe, and houses fer asonder,
In siknesse nor in meschief to visít
The ferreste in his parisshe, muche and lit
Upon his feet, and in his hand a staf.
That first he wroghte and afterward he taught
Out of the gospel he tho word
And this figure he added eek therto,
For if a preest be foul, on whom we trust
And shame it is, if a prest tak
A shiten shepherde and a clen
By his clennesse how that his sheep sholde lyv
And ran to Londoun, unto Seint
To seken hym a chaunterie for soul
Or with a bretherhed to been withhold
But dwelte at hoom and kept
So that the wolf ne made it nat myscari
He was a shepherde, and noght a mercenari
And though he hooly were and vertuous,
He was to synful man nat despitous,
But in his techyng díscreet and benygn
To drawen folk to hevene by fairness
By good ensample, this was his bisyness
But it were any persone obstinat,
What so he were, of heigh or lough estat,
Hym wolde he snybben sharply for the nonys.
preest I trowe that nowher noon ys.
He waited after no pompe and reverenc
He taughte, but first he folw
With hym ther was a Plowman, was his brother,
That hadde y-lad of dong ful many a fother;
swynkere and a good was he,
Lyvynge in pees and parfit charitee.
God loved he best, with al his hool
s, thogh him gamed or smert
thresshe, and therto dyke and delv
For Cristes sake, for every povr
Withouten hire, if it lay in his myght.
de he ful faire and wel,
In a tabard he rood upon a mer
Ther was also a Reve and a Miller
A Somnour and a Pardoner also,
A Maunciple, and myself,—ther were namo.
The Millere was a stout carl for the non
Ful byg he was of brawn and eek of bon
d wel, for over-al, ther he cam,
At wrastlynge he wolde have alwey the ram.
Ther nas no dore that he nolde heve of harr
Or breke it at a rennyng with his heed.
His berd as any sowe or fox was reed,
And therto brood, as though it were a spad
Upon the cop right of his nose he had
A werte, and thereon stood a toft of herys,
A swerd and a bokeler bar he by his syd
His mouth as greet was as a greet forneys;
He was a janglere and a goliardeys,
And that was moost of synne and harlotri
Wel koude he stelen corn and tollen thri
And yet he hadde a thombe of gold, pardee.
A whit cote and a blew hood wer
pipe wel koude he blowe and sowne,
And therwithal he broghte us out of town
A gentil Maunciple was ther of a templ
For to be wise in byynge of vitaill
For, wheither that he payde or took by taill
Algate he wayted so in his achaat
That he was ay biforn and in good staat.
Now is nat that of God a ful fair grac
The wisdom of an heep of lern
s hadde he mo than thri
That weren of lawe expert and curious,
Of whiche ther weren a duszeyne in that hous
Worthy to been stywardes of rente and lond
Of any lord that is in Eng
In honour dettelees, but if he were wood,
Or lyve as scarsly as hym list desir
for to helpen al a shir
And yet this Manciple sette hir aller capp
His berd was shave as ny as ever he kan;
His heer was by his erys round y-shorn;
Y-lyk a staf, ther was no calf y-sen
Wel koude he kepe a gerner and a bynn
Ther was noon auditour koude on him wynn
Wel wiste he, by the droghte and by the reyn,
The yeldynge of his seed and of his greyn.
s sheep, his neet, his day
His swyn, his hors, his stoor, and his pultry
And by his covenant yaf the rekenyng
Syn that his lord was twenty yeer of ag
There koude no man brynge hym in arrerag
There nas baillif, ne hierde, nor oother hyn
That he ne knew his sleighte and his covyn
They were adrad of hym as of the deeth.
His wonyng was ful fair upon an heeth;
His lord wel koude he plesen subtilly,
To yeve and lene hym of his owen
And have a thank, and yet a cote and hood.
He was a wel good wrighte, a carpenter.
sat upon a ful good stot,
That was al pomely grey, and hight
A long surcote of pers upon he had
And by his syde he baar a rusty blad
Of Northfolk was this Reve of which I tell
Biside a toun men clepen Bald
d he was as is a frere, about
And evere he rood the hyndreste of oure rout
A Somonour was ther with us in that place,
fleem he was, with eyen narw
As hoot he was and lecherous as a sparw
Ther nas quyk-silver, lytarge, ne brymstoon,
Boras, ceruce, ne oille of tartr
That hym myghte helpen of his whelk
Wel loved he garleek, oynons, and eek lek
And for to drynken strong wyn, reed as blood.
Thanne wolde he speke, and crie as he were wood.
And whan that he wel dronken hadde the wyn,
s hadde he, two or thre,
No wonder is, he herde it al the day;
And eek ye knowen wel how that a jay
Kan clepen "Watte" as wel as kan the pope.
But whoso koude in oother thyng hym grope,
Thanne hadde he spent al his philosophi
He was a gentil harlot and a kynd
A good felawe to have his concubyn
A twelf month, and excuse hym att
ly a fynch eek koude he pulle.
And if he foond owher a good felaw
techen him to have noon awe,
In swich caas, of the erch
s soule were in his purs;
For in his purs he sholde y-punysshed be:
But wel I woot he ly
Of cursyng oghte ech gilty man him dred
For curs wol slee, right as assoillyng savith;
And also war him of a
In daunger hadde he at his owen
And knew hir conseil, and was al hir reed.
A gerland hadde he set upon his heed,
As greet as it were for an al
A bokeleer hadde he maad him of a cak
With hym ther rood a gentil Pardoner
Of Rouncivale, his freend and his compeer,
That streight was comen fro the court of Rom
Ful loude he soong, "Com hider, lov
This Somonour bar to hym a stif burdoun;
Was nevere trompe of half so greet a soun.
This Pardoner hadde heer as yelow as wex,
But smothe it heeng as dooth a strike of flex;
But thynne it lay, by colpons, oon and oon;
Hym thoughte he rood al of the new
Dischevelee, save his cappe, he rood al bar
Swiche glarynge eyen hadde he as an har
A vernycle hadde he sowed upon his capp
His walet lay biforn hym in his lapp
Bret-ful of pardoun, comen from Rome al hoot.
A voys he hadde as smal as hath a goot.
No berd hadde he, ne nevere shold
As smothe it was as it were late y-shav
I trowe he were a geldyng or a mar
But of his craft, fro Berwyk into War
Ne was ther swich another pardoner;
For in his male he hadde a pilw
He seyde he hadde a gobet of the seyl
Peter hadde, whan that he went
Upon the see, til Jesu Crist hym hent
He hadde a croys of latoun, ful of ston
And in a glas he hadd
Upon a day he gat hym moore money
Than that the person gat in month
He made the person and the peple his ap
He was in chirche a noble ecclesiast
Wel koude he rede a lessoun or a stori
But alderbest he song an offertori
He moste preche, and wel affile his tong
silver, as he ful wel koud
Therefore he song the murierly and loud
Now have I toold you shortly, in a claus
Thestaat, tharray, the nombre, and eek the caus
In Southwerk, at this gentil hostelry
How that we baren us that ilk
Whan we were in that hostelrie alyght;
And after wol I telle of our viag
And al the remenaunt of oure pilgrimag
But first, I pray yow, of youre curteisy
That ye narette it nat my vileyny
Thogh that I pleynly speke in this mateer
Ne thogh I speke hir word
For this ye knowen al-so wel as I,
Whoso shal telle a tale after a man,
He moot reherce, as ny as evere he kan,
Everich a word, if it be in his charg
Al speke he never so rud
Or ellis he moot telle his tale untrew
He may nat spare, althogh he were his brother;
He moot as wel seye o word as another.
Crist spak hymself ful brode in hooly writ,
And wel ye woot no vileynye is it.
Eek Plato seith, whoso kan hym red
s moote be cosyn to the ded
Also I prey yow to foryeve it me,
Al have I nat set folk in hir degree
Heere in this tale, as that they shold
My wit is short, ye may wel understond
And to the soper sette he us anon,
d us with vitaille at the best
Strong was the wyn and wel to drynke us lest
For to been a marchal in an hall
A large man he was with eyen step
A fairer burgeys was ther noon in Chep
Boold of his speche, and wys, and well y-taught,
Eek thereto he was right a myrie man,
And after soper pleyen he bigan,
Ye been to me right welcome, hert
For by my trouthe, if that I shal nat ly
I saugh nat this yeer so myrie a compaigny
s in this herberwe as is now.
Fayn wolde I doon yow myrth
And of a myrthe I am right now bythoght,
To doon yow ese, and it shal cost
And wel I woot, as ye goon by the wey
Ye shapen yow to talen and to pley
ly confort ne myrthe is noon
by the weye doumb as a stoon;
And therfore wol I maken yow disport,
As I seyde erst, and doon yow som confort.
And if you liketh alle, by oon assent,
For to stonden at my jugg
And for to werken as I shal yow sey
, whan ye riden by the wey
But ye be myrie, I wol yeve yow myn heed!
Hoold up youre hond, withouten moor
Us thoughte it was noght worth to make it wys,
And graunted hym withouten moore avys,
And bad him seye his verdit, as hym lest
"Lordynges," quod he, "now herkneth for the best
But taak it nought, I prey yow, in desdeyn;
This is the poynt, to speken short and pleyn,
That ech of yow, to short
To Caunterbury-ward, I mene it so,
And homward he shal tellen other
Of aventúres that whilom han bifall
And which of yow that bereth hym beste of all
That is to seyn, that telleth in this caas
s of best sentence and moost solaas,
Shal have a soper at oure aller cost,
Whan that we come agayn fro Caunterbury.
I wol myselven gladly with yow ryd
Shal paye al that we spenden by the wey
This thyng was graunted, and oure oth
With ful glad herte, and preyden hym also
And that he wolde been oure governour,
And sette a soper at a certeyn pris;
In heigh and lough; and thus, by oon assent,
We been acorded to his jugg
And therupon the wyn was fet anon;
, whan that day gan for to spryng
Up roos oure Hoost and was oure aller cok,
And gadrede us togidre alle in a flok;
And forth we riden, a litel moore than paas,
Unto the wateryng of Seint Thomas;
And there oure Hoost bigan his hors arest
Ye woot youre foreward and I it yow record
Lat se now who shal telle the first
Whoso be rebel to my jugg
Shal paye for all that by the wey is spent.
Now draweth cut, er that we ferrer twynn
He which that hath the shorteste shal bigynn
Sire Knyght," quod he, "my mayster and my lord
Now draweth cut, for that is myn accord.
Cometh neer," quod he, "my lady Prioress
And ye, sire Clerk, lat be your shamefastness
Ne studieth noght. Ley hond to, every man."
Anon to drawen every wight bigan,
And, shortly for to tellen as it was,
Were it by áventúre, or sort, or cas,
The sothe is this, the cut fil to the Knyght,
Of which ful blithe and glad was every wyght;
And telle he moste his tale, as was resoun,
As ye han herd; what nedeth word
And whan this goode man saugh that it was so,
As he that wys was and obedient
To kepe his foreward by his free assent,
What, welcome be the cut, a Godd
Now lat us ryde, and herkneth what I sey
And with that word we ryden forth oure wey
And he bigan with right a myrie cheer
His tale anon, and seyde in this manér
title: The Canterbury Tales: General Prologue
